pageContext.desc: Letters to the Ames family of Lake County, Illinois, include several from a son who fought in the Civil War and died in the Battle of Shiloh.

Dear Sir:
In reply to your letter of the 13th inst I have the honor to state that no order has been received for the discharge of soldiers whose term expires prior to the 1st of December 1865, No special action is needed in your case you will I think soon be mustered out and sent home for final payment.
Very Respectfully R J Oglesby Governor

Alkali Jan 18th 1876
Francelia
Your uncle Lize has Ben a thinking a bout writing to you for some time and at last- he has got at it. your uncle Philander is Down To North Platt City at work he was swell the last I heard from him I am at the ranch a mustering fifteen head of horses some of them are Prety Bad to Pick tell your Pa that I have had no Chance to get those Deer hids this winter I'm do busy that I have no time but I will get them if I Can the Indians ar a going to Be pretty bad This Spring I expect- they have crossed over Donth On the war Path the Government is a preparing fer

Trouble with them, I think I shall go to the Black hills in the Spring if I do not get Pretty Big wages here The Ground is covered with Snow and it is Pretty Cold to Day I supose you are a going to school this winter and ho is a keeping your school this winter the Cattle have all gone West this year and we will have a long ways to go after them
I do not see any one only once and a while Dranalins some times Stayes Over night with me
So I Get a little lonly at times
One mild and a half [??] I Get my male I think the Snow will melt of pretty soon and then we will have some more Warm weather. 
I have not washed the Dishes nor swept the house yet this Day and at

Olnt
is all most Noon do you see I'm keeping old Batchalors hall
Tell Emma that Next time I write I will write her and tell Philo then he may look out for letter Some Day. tell Philo that he ought to be out here with his bow and arow to go on the war path with the Indians
So Good By for this time
from Elijah E Ames

June 21st 1861
Dear Brother We were ordered from camp, Scott- to encamp at Alton on the 18th this being our first march we received instructions as to the manner in which we should arrange our baggage on the day previous to our march we received wharmer socks. We left Freeport- about -10 AM and arrived in a Alton at 6 A.M. the next day. The conductor on the second train was killed he was standing on the roof? of a train and crossing a bridge and was struck on the head and killed instantly. We are all well there are three regiments here with us making four in all To\he regiments except one have there tents that are being of Heckers
We have been on drill but once since we were here and that has

before the U S inspector we were contending rifles we were judged the best drilled regiment on the ground we therefore will receive rifles as soon as they can be procured which will not be long and shall be the first called on to fight which we expect will be soon after we get our arms. We had a to move a short distance from where we now are on to the bank up the river. we have been permitted to take a bath in the river every day. The climate is much warmer here than when we left. in many places the farmers were harvesting winter wheat and the spring grain was all headed out and some corn was in tassal, the water is very good but not as good as we left. the camp is on high ground two miles north of the city.
Yours,
Joel W. Ames

Direct to Alton Ill
Care of Capt Jones
15 Reg ILL volunteers

15TH Reg. Ill. Vol. JULY 22, -61
DEAR BROTHER,
I RECEIVED YOURS THE DAY THAT WE LEFT CAMP POPE* I  AM WELL AND FEELL
MUCH BETTER THAN WHILE AT Alton WE HAVE MUCH BETTER WATER THAN WE HAD
AT CAMP POPE*. THE BOYS ARE ALL IN GOOD SPIRITS WITH A FEW EXCEPTIONS. 
WE LEFT CAMP POPE ON THE 18TH AND ON ACCOUNT OF THERE NOT BEING 
BUT TWO BOATS FOR THREE REGIMENTS WE STAY IN ALTON. 
We loged? in the out-houses and shops of the old states prison.
we left the next day on the Meteor for St. Charles in Missouri as we entered the mouth of the Missouri river we met with a 2nd accident - a sergeant of the ? Co was jerked off the boat while dipping water from the side of

the boat and drowned he kept up 
until he was reached with a 
small boat and just as we thought
him safe he went down to rise no
more. As we assended this muddy
stream we passed one small landing
where they gave cheers for Jeff Davis
but it being after dark we were 
unable to see any one but one of
our musicians in response to their
cheers played the rogues march
which soon silenced them.
We (crossed out: left) arrived in St. Charles about
eleven Oclock in the evening and
marched into camp with the 17
and Hecker regiments who went 
the day before they left the next morning
on the cars they were fired at in a
place where one was killed and unclear
wounded we heard that they killed
fifteen and took some prisoners but 
this needs confermation.
We are still encamped at St

Charles we did expect to leave
here yesterday and went as far 
as to strike our tents, and march
down through town and back again
the reason of our not going was 
because they did not dare to travel on
the road in the night on account of
the danger of the tracks being torn
up we expect to go today
but do not know for certain.
The guard sent (crossed out: up) to guard the
Train that was to take us consisting
of companies I and K of the 21st
regiment of the Illinois troops were
quartered in our regiment last
night; they had several skermishes
while coming through they took three
prisoners which they brought with them
who were released this morning on
taking the oath of allegiance. they
also killed one captain and several
horses their riders escaping
they brought tobacco from the

house that they tore down
belonging to a rebel, and 
two double blankets which they 
lost while running there was but
one shot fired at our boys in every
case the rebels were running.
While I write I asertain for certain
that we shall leave here this afternoon.
The harvesting and haying
is nearly all finished in this
part of the country it is a fine
looking place here, St. Charles
is one of the prettiest townes I
ever saw it is on the bank of 
the river and is high enough
to be neat and clean corn looks;
well write as soon as you got
this Direct to St Charles Company I
15 Ill. Reg. and [pass?] on the
letter P.M. please Forward if gone
Yours. Joel W. Ames.

Rolla Oct. 2nd 1861
Dear Brother I received your
last in due time and would
have answered it sooner if
we had not been under marching
orders on Tuesday night of last
week we received orders to be ready
to march at 8 A.M. the next day
the cooks worked all night to
have three days rations ready
for the march the 14th also
had marching orders and
went in the morning and
we did not receive orders 
to leave the collision
that night stopped all
trains from St. Louis to
take us away so we eat our
three days rations in camp
in stead of on the cars for
Jeffersoncity.

On Saturday we were
ordered to march on foot
for Jeffersoncity and about
3 P.M. we succeeded in marching
six miles before encampping
at 8 in the evening on
the ground with nothing but
our coats and blankets over
us and an oil cloth underneat
however we slept very comfortable
The next morning after
breakfast we again resumed
our march until noon when
we were overtaken by a messenger
who brought orders to return
and go by railroad the 13.15 and
Illinois regiments and
4th Iowa are waiting here now
The country that we traveled
over was very rough and 
rocky and our course was up
the bottom of the little

Prig there being no other
place for a road you can 
easily trace our path on the
map for the Pacific railroad 
runs up the ravine when
we marched on its way from 
Rolla to Springfield but there
is no track although the road is
cut and graded for many miles
the banks of the creek was lined 
with grapes wild hops of a large
size and [Paupaus?] which were
not eatable because the frost had
mot bitten them. I am well
again today being the first
for nearly two weeks that I
have been able to do duty,
and on our last march
my knapsack and gun were
carried and on our return
I was compelled to [ride?] Arthur

was taken Sick the night
we (crossed out: were) arrived in our
old camping ground he has
some kind of a fever but
I do not know what but 
I hope he will soon be better
Several of the boys are 
going home on furloughs
to recruit after a severe
fit of sickness they start
to morrow. If Elijah has
not left before this reaches
you tell him he had better
get a good pair of boots to
bring with him as the 
United States furnishes nothing 
but shoes. Our pay has not 
come yet the 13 Ill. were paid
last week and we supposed we
were to be but not so we
were to be but not so [we?]
are at the tail end of [?] all
Yours Joel W. Ames

1861
Camp Mount View Nov 1st
Dear Brother!
It is so long since either of
us wrote that I have forgotten
which wrote last, but however
I shall break the ice and I hope 
you will follow in the wake.
Elijah and my self, are well. 
We are now encamped on Deer creek
14 miles southeast of Warsaw
where we expected to figh Price,
but when we arrived he was not
here. Most of the country between
Tipton and Warsaw is a beautiful
and rich prairie well calculated
to keep stock wood and water
is very plenty for a prairie-
country. a great many houses [were?]
left - In some few the women
appeared to be collected for self
preservation for as we passed

some dozen or more would
rush out to the fence to look at 
us as we passed and the only
mankind to be seen was a small
boy or so the towns and villages
nearly deserted only a few groceries
are open in any of them. The
country is very thinly settled. 
We are now waiting for 
provisions our trains went back to
Tipton on monday, and will
return in about a week. The 
picket guard keep bringing in
prisoners and provisions when 
Price came through the [secessionists?]
became so bold that the home
guards could easily detect them
and now they are very busy in
pointing them out. I was on
picket and the consequence was
that I had all the honey I wished
to eat.

Crowpill Bridgwater Jan / 22 [?]
Dear Fred, I received your letter
and feel sorry the cold weather has
punished you so much.
I was very glad the Venezualan? affair
is settled, because there is a very
great unwillingness here to have
a war with the United states. I know
yours is a mixed people, but many
here have relations in america
people who have tried to get on here
and have failed from some cause
or other and have com to your 
country to they their fortunes anew
Our hearts have gone out after
them, wishing them God speed
but they having nothing to thank 
the old country for, do not recip
-rocate? the feeling, we never felt
angry with the president Cleveland's
Message, but looked upon it, as the
speech of a rebellious offspring, 
very different was the feeling
when the Queen's grandson, sent

his message to president Kruger
this country was like a boiling
pot and all classes were up to
boiling pitch, the lower classes
especially and people would buy
nothing made in Germany and
the German Bands in the streets
were not allowed to play anything
but Rule Britannia or God Save
the Queen.
I believe a million men could
have been enroled within a week
Your editor of the Vernon Country
Census, stated last year that
Germany had 4 Million 6 hundred
thousand soldiers while we had
only 6 hundred thousand. 
Now I think that is misleading 
because the Germans have all
to serve three years in the army
and their names remain on the
army list up to the age limit
although they are scattered

all over the world. The German
Census, lately taken, shows that
there are only two Millions 
in their Government pay, and 
that includes Army, Navy, and
the Civil service.
Our Volunteers are very much
of the same sort of stuff that
faught for your Northern states
back in the 60s with this exception
They are already drilled, they
at present count a quarter of
a million, but the wave of those 
who have passed through the 
ranks is legion. I am one of
the oldest specimens, I was the
first volunteer in Bridgewater
I took the oath of allegiance in
October 1859, at the time of the
French scare, served 14 1/4 years,
during which time I won the Bronze
medal, as best shot in the country
and in 12, won a Queen's Badge

at Wimbledon as one of the sixty
best shots in the Kingdom. I won many
prizes and one year won 30 sovereigns
in Money prizes. I can shoot as
well now as ever, and last year
I notified that I was ready to fall
in if required, although past the age limit.
We had an interesting match some
time ago, 15 of the old hands,
shot a match against 15 of
the present, at 200, 500 and 600
yards. we won handsomely, have
challenged them since, but they won't 
accept. I don't hesitate to say that among
the volunteers, past and present, will be
found, some of the finest shots in the
world, we have ((12?)) Companies here, there
member was decreasing 13 Months ago
but on the German scare last year
30 young fellows joined in a week,
among them was my 2 grandsons,
the only 2 old enough. They I know
would volunteer for active service
if a war broke out,

Crowpill Bridgwater May 2nd 1898
Dear Fred, I received your long letter and 
sent you a paper of the days date, as usual.
Your Brother Lewis, must be a though one
I have lately heard from my sister and
have written her, telling her she owes
you a letter, and giving her your add
-ress, she has had a bad attack of
Influenza but is got pretty well over
it, I have at last succeeded in getting
My Brother Robert to give me a photo
for you and enclose it, it is
a very true likeness.
Those old school books that you
Mean cannot be got now for love
or money, such as we used to read 
the best History of England, I have on
record? is in the form of letters from
a gentleman to his son, at College,
by Oliver Goldsmith, but I will
get you a catalogue from some

Old book seller and send it on
and you will then see just the
class of Books that are to be found
at such places. I would give you 
a taste of old Books if you visited
me one printed 1612, written by
purchase and I think called the pilgrim
1102 pages in it he gives the account
of the spaniard's in America, how
they marched into the uncalthy? places
with the Cross in our hand and
the sward in the other, and those
who would not fall down at ?
and worship the cross, were slain 
with the sword, Gold was carried 
away by them by shiploads but
a good part of it fell in the hands
of our old Sea Dogs.
It tells how the native priests were
slain and their Temples stripped
by the spaniards, well they have

gone a long time without their
Pay but vengeance is mine saith
the Lord. I will repay, and however
the quarrel came about, or who
is at fault, between spain and 
America, I see plainly the time
is not for distant when the 
Spanish will be driven from the
land, they murdered so many
innocent people in 300 years ago.
This war, of 10 days standing has
sent the wheat and flour up by
leaps and bounds, the bread
rose Monday from 5 to 6 a loaf
and on Monday next will go up
another 1 a loaf, sugar has also
gone up considerably. 
My wife is still very ill the Doctor 
has been coming here since
18th October, was here yesterday
and said he thought Mrs was

better I have an old nurse for
her by day, and I have to attend
to her myself by night, so you
see I have had a hard time of it,
but it is only paying old debts, as
when I had Influenza she nursed 
me singlehanded
and this I consciously believe 
that what measure ye give will
be measured to you again,
I suppose if the war lasts any longer?
Charlie will be called upon
to serve in the American Army
I sincerely hope he wont as it would 
be bad for you. so now goodbye
and God bless you.
With Kind regards to
Mrs H and all the family
I am
Your Affectionate Cousin
Jared?

Crowpill Road Bridgwater
Somerset
England
Jan 18th 10H
Dear Cousin Amy
I received
your letter, and am very
sorry to hear of your fathers
death, it is a sad loss to
you all, and especially
to your mother I could well
sympathize with her having
lost my partner, after 44
years together, and at the
time of life where one wants
company the most, I am

left entirely alone now
as I had the misfortune to
lose my old housekeeper
last year, who had worked
for us twenty years, but
in your Mother's case I hope
between you, you will make 
her life as comfortable as
it is possible
I had not written to your
Father, for some time 
I am sorry to say, as I
had to give up a good 
deal of correspondence 
after I lost my wife, I write
once a week to my daughter,

and about once a quarter,
to my sister, in Newzealand,
but my Time is fully occupied
as I have a large garden
but the worst of it is the
weather has been so bad
for the last year, as April
18th the frost destroyed
nearly all the fruit and
then we had no summer 
and almost continuous
rain, since last June,
and most of the corn and 
late Hay, was spoiled
and up to now I cannot
go into the garden to do
anything it is so soaked

with wet, but the season
is so mild up to now, that
I picked enough Primroses
yesterday, for a buttonhole
and the strawberries are
in blossom all about 
the place. I am well pleased
to hear you so well suited
in a husband, and hope
your happiness will be
continued for a good long
life, please give my Kind 
regards to all your good
people, and believe me
to your affectionate cousin
J {{Hardue?]]

Crowpill Bridgwater April 1st/00
Dear Fred I received your letter of 
sympathy, this morning. I have received 
many, for my wife was much respected 
by all who came in contact with her 
and a more devoted wife, no man 
ever had. I feel very lonely now 
without her after being 44 years 
together. I had no time for correspondence. 
I assure you we had a great deal 
of trouble with her, towards the last, 
her sister Miss Parsons, stayed with 
her the last 3 months, but we had 
a nurse by night, and Doctor sometime 
twice a day, but all was no 
good the heart gave way.
I am in a big house by myself but I 
get a Charwoman, who has worked for 
us 16 years, to come in every morning 
and sometimes all day, and she 
does all that is necessary without any 
telling, in that way I am very well off.

I have sent you several papers and the
photos of the volunteers my grandson
is out to Cape Town by this time
Out of 50 Bridgwater chaps, only nine
passed all the Tests, he was one of
them, but some more were taken after
making about 20 from here.
Hardly any of them intend coming back
again, I told you long ago. our people
were in Africa, and were come to stay
I am glad your people have followed
up the Chinese, with respect to the
open door, that is all we want in
China, Equality of opportunity, that
is all we want in Africa, or anywhere
but we are an Island of busy bees,
which multiply rapidly, and where
they swarm, they must go abroad
for material to make honey, and
if they are interrupted they will
very probably sting, those who interfere with
them. I don't think the present

government are likely to fall into the
same trap, with Kruger & co, as Gladstone 
did, it will be a costly war, and they
are following it up regardless of men
and money, it is like a rising Tide
Thousands of men pouring into Africa
day after day, which it is impossible
to stand against, and many many
thousands are clamoring to go.
My Brother Sidney's youngest son
is at the front, with the City of London
volunteers, he is chief signaller with
them, and a capital shot, as well.
We are getting fine weather here now, but 
a frost every morning, and very cold
All sorts of vegetables are very scarce
and good Cheese difficult to get at
any price. good American is selling 
at big prices, tell your people, to send
it along, they will get good returns,
Yes, Fred, I received the photos and
I have been trying to study the face
of your grandson, it is a good

face. and if he is spared he will be
clever, but not Crafty. It is an Artists
face. Tell his parents to watch his
bent? at school and particularly
notice if he takes Kindly to Drawing,
When you write again say whether
your Brothers, and Sister, are alive
and well, I have not heard from
my sister, for a long time. but my
two Brothers are all right, Edward
spends a tremendous lot of time
to public business, county, and
Parish Council, guardian &c
I hope to begin gardening to-morrow,
potato planting &c. but the season
is very backward no ? blossons
showing yet. Sometimes the Trees are
a sheet of blosson, in March.
and now, with Kind regards to all
your folks, I beg to receive your
loving cousin Fred.
PS. I can give you a shake down for a month, if you will come this summer
if the wife won't come, come yourself
F Harden ?

Sussex
Dec: 21st
Dear Uncle
No doubt you
will be surprised to have
a letter from your niece. We
mislaid your address, or we
should have written before
I hope you and Auntie are
quite well, wishing you all
a prosperous new year. I am
now thirteen years of age, 
but am still at school,
which I like very much. We
are having very bad
weather at Brighton. Dada
has been laid up for a

you have time. The King? is staying here 
at present because he has had an 
illness. This visit makes Brighton very 
busy indeed. Dada, Mother and sisters 
send their best wishes to you all. I 
think I have said all, and must now 
draw to a close but will say more next 
time. 
I remain 
your loving niece 
Nellie Mullins

Dear Cousin
received your kind letter in August last &? many thanks for it I trust this will find you + all your family well. I have been going to write so many times but something are other has prevented me many thanks for paper you so kindly sent me am glad to say me my husband children mothers + sisters at present are well. Yes I have 2 sisters simple? Rosa Brewer the eldest of us all you ask what wages

they get Rosa is housekeeper she get ￡20 a year + all found at present Matilda is living with me as I am glad with help in this line of busness. My sisters thank you very much for offering them a house if they like to come with you its very kind of you but they do like the thoughts of leaving England + their old home. Dear Cousin We were not aware of our high Accent on Mothers side + we felt quite flattered when reading your letter although my fathers family were a well to do family. I must tell you a little unclear

bit concerning my grand father that was fathers father + his 11 sons + 3 daughters a few years since the 11 sons + father reaped togethers? like Joseph + his Brethern + grand father kept in part? of his sons + the neices nephews + grand sons bound the sheaves people often speak of it as its not often anything like that occur Fathers Father + all his brothers were farmers + they all had long family + lived to a good old age except my father + he was one of the youngest + was only 52. when he died his 2 brothers that are left one is 83 + the other 84. I wish dear Mother had been alive she would have

been so pleased to have heard from you as she often used to say she did not seem to have any relations left on her father side but its wrong of us to wish her back as she had a lot of trouble to bring us up as we were so young when Father died + being in a Farm, dear Mother so easy that was robbed on every hand that she lost all she had + had to work hard to rear us but when we were old enough to earn our own living we did what we could for dear Mother + only wish we had her now if only to speak to its hard to loose a good Mother. now dear cousin my Husband unclear sisters joins/ me in love to you all wishing you a Happy [Hmas/]] when it

comes hoping to hear from you again soon sorry to see by your letter you had been unwell but trust now you are better We were pleased to see that all the war is finished + that America did so well. Must now say good bye. 
From you loving
Cousin L. Coles

87 Southover Street
Brighton
Sussex
England
My Dear Cousin

    We received your kind letter and pleased to hear you are quite well.  We should very much like to see you all.  How nice to be living in your own house.  I dare say you do feel lonely at times especially in the winter are

P.S.  Would you mind telling us what the fare from here to ?? would be

there any wolfs about there we should like to come over to America if you think I should be bettering myself.

  My wages are 28shillings per week.  My clothes and boots are found for me.  And at the end of twenty five years service I am entitled to a pound per week pension as long as I live.  Will you please tell me what you

really think would be best.  Is there plenty of work to be done near where you are.  We know A. Carpenter has lately returned from America.  he resided there for twenty years And during that time he saved nearly a thousand pounds.  And since his return to England he has nearly spent it all on drink.  he used to do contract work At the last.  we are all of us total ??

the curse of England to ?? drink the costs are so fearfully high there we pay 9 shilling per week for rent.  we let to holiday people in the ?? or we shouldn't be able to get on at all.  the children wear out so many boots they seem to be always wanting something, will you please write an dlet us know if it would be worth ?? our ?? to ?? to ??.  give our kind love to your wife and Daughter and except the love your self.  from your affectionate cousin.  S. Mullin

May 7th 1865  Camp near Petersburg Va.  I am well but quite sore.  we marched 198 miles in 9 days and I understand that we will have to march to Alexandria 8 miles of Washington.  I stood the march very well.  I got my Knapsack halled 9 days.  The weather is fine.  I have not had any letter since I wrote last.  I have but a few minutes to write.  I hope that these lines will find you all well and may we soon meet again.  tell the children that papa is comeing home soon.  may God's blessing rest on you all ??.

    I Truly    R D Ames

Miss D.M. Harden
6 DURLEIGH RD
BRIDGWATER, SOMERSETT
Mr R.H. Harden cannot remember much except to know a family of Brewers.  My mother remembers something of a family going to America & on journey over the water the woman died.

  My family lived at corner of Queens St at one time.  Do you think there is a connection in that house near Quentoch Electric Co which has a figure of Napoleon over the door.  This place I understand belonged to a Brewer

family -- this may be the stone castle.  Why not try the Brewer families of the town -- also Mr. Perzner may be able to trace the history of that house.  I have looked at all the old letters we have at home & cannot find anything.  In the back of my mind -- I think I can remember my grand father mentioning this cousin.  If I can help please let me know.  I have 2 Great Aunts -- family name HYDON in America -- maybe they could help.  if so -- will supply address
A.L. BACON.
CAIRN RECKON.KENNELS
NORTH HACKENSACK
N. JERSEY
